poem:
**Crosswords at Twilight**  
  
Tim and Pru, with pencils poised,  
love spelled out in black and white,  
grid by grid, an evening spent,  
across the page, words took flight.  
  
In the quiet of bedside dreams,  
letters tangled in tender threads,  
Araucaria's clues entwined,  
lovers parsing what love said.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Letters: Timothy West obituary Timothy West and his wife, Prunella Scales, had a great fondness for Guardian crosswords, particularly those set by John Graham (Araucaria), whom Pru described as her “favourite extramarital bedtime companion”. At John’s 90th birthday party hosted by the Guardian in 2011, Tim described how he and Pru had fallen in love while solving an Araucaria puzzle. My wife and I were thrilled to be invited by Tim to their home, so". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
